The Diccionario de Autoridades defined "correría" as "hostility and damage done by people of war, entering and running into the enemy country".

Medinilla is not precise in the translation and the original idea seems blurred, as he removes the idea that Utopians do not enslave Alaopolitans because Utopians weren't involved in that war on their own account. According to Lupton, the name "Nephelogetis" comes from the Greek word "Νεφελόγεταs", meaning "Cloudlanders), and "Alaopolitas", from the Greek "Άλαοπολίταs", meaning "men of Blindville"(1985, 244 n. 2). In contrast, Logan (1989), suggests different meanings: the former, defined as "People Born from the Clouds" and the latter as "Citizens of a Country without People" (91 n. 111). Yale agrees with Logan and deepens on Lucian's influence (More 1965, 500). Medinilla applies Spanish spelling rules to "Nephelogetis", being rendered as "nefologetas". The spelling "nofologetas" and "aleopolitas" appear as this in the text.

The Spanish translator does not transmit the same idea than in the original in the sentence "modo corporibus absit uis, hactenus irascuntur uti" "but without personal violence, their anger goes no further" (1965, 201 ll. 36-37). Medinilla renders it as "no fantándoles fuerzas corporales, de tal suerte se embravecen" (in English, "not giving them bodily strength, in such a way they become enraged").

Neither Medinilla nor Robinson make a literal translation of this segment. Especially, when it comes with the Latin sentence "Quicquid percussori praefiniunt, hoc geminant ei qui uiuum e pro­scriptis aliquem ad se perduxerint, quum ipsos quoque proscriptos praemiis iisdem, addita etiam impunitate, contra socios inuitant" (in English, "Whatever reward they fix for an assassin, they double for the man who brings any of the denounced parties alive to them. They actually offer the same rewards, with a guarantee of personal safety, to the persons proscribed, if they will turn against their fellows" (1965, 205 l. 5-9)). The Spanish translator reads "y cualquier premio que prometen al que así diere muerte le señalan doblado para aque que trujere vivo o preso algunos de los bandido, y aún ellos mismos les premian con las mismas honras, asegurándoles las vidas si se presentan, convidándolos con esto contra sus amigos" (in English, "And any reward they promise to anyone who kills them in this way is doubled for those who bring back alive or prisoner some of the bandits, and they themselves reward them with the same honors, assuring their lives if they show up, inviting them with this against their friends"). The 1551 English text says "What soeuer is prescribed vnto him that killeth any of the proclamed persons, that is dobled to him that bringeth any of the same to them aliue: yea, and to the proclamed persones them selfes, if they wil chaunge their mindes and come into them, takinge their partes, they profer the same greate rewardes with pardon, and suerty of their liues", deviating from the original idea.
The phrase "cum fide" is rendered by Medinilla as "con toda fidelidad y firmeza" (in English, "full of fidelity and steadiness").

The Spanish translator selects "almonedear" to render the Latin "mercandi". The Tesoro de la Lengua defines the noun "almoneda" as "the sale of public things that is made with the intervention of justice and before notary and a public minister, called crier, because speaking aloud he proposes the thing he is selling and the price they give for it and because they bid each other and increase the price [...]" (1611, fol. 56v). This significantly alterns the original meaning of the sentence, as the translator adds his particular reimagination of market scenarios.
The name "Zapoletis" derives from the Greek ζα- and πολίτηs, meaning "busy sellers" (Yale 504 n. 206/8).
Another instance where Medinilla mistranslates numbers: instead of "five hundred miles", he introduces "cincuenta" ("fifty").

Medinilla inserts the noun "mercenarios" as a reference to the Zapoletas although it is not mentioned in the Latin Utopia. This word does not appear in the Tesoro de la Lengua nor the Diccionario de Autoridades, but it is defined in the Diccionario de la Lengua Española as "a soldier or a troop who serves a foreign power in war as a stipend". According to Yale, the 1518 editions omitted a note on the Swiss deemed as mercenaries (1965: 504 n. 206/8) Also, in contrast with chapter six, Medinilla translates the Latin word "assis" as "cornado" instead of "blanca". This is defined in the Tesoro de la Lengua as "formerly a very low grade coin". The value of the "cornado" is lower than a "blanca", according to the Diccionario de Autoridades. Similarly, Robinson uses "halfpenye" instead of "farthing". The OED explains "halfpenye" was "a coin of the English (later British) currency of half the value of a penny; the amount represented by this, a sum equivalent to two farthings". See note ** for further information.

The Spanish governor alters the last Latin segment "e quibus aliquem uirtutis probatae uirum totius exercitus summae praeficiunt" (in English, "they appoint some man of tried valor to command the whole army" (Yale 209, l. 19)) by adding a position offered in the Spanish army: "Capitán General". The Diccionario de Autoridades establishes that the "capitán general" is "who commands an army of land, or a navy of sea, with immediate authority to the King and the Council", which makes sense with the delegated task.

Medinilla renders "substituunt" as "substituyen" ("to substitute") and it blurs the original sense of the verb. In this case, it means "appoint a substitution", as is rendered in Yale "For him they have two substitutes" (209 l. 20). Also, he opts for "caudillo" to translate "duce", which means "guide to the army [...], also meaning captain" according to the Tesoro de la Lengua (fol. 212v).
It is interesting that Medinilla adds "cuñados" (in English, "brother-in-law" to expand the meaning of "affines" ("relatives").

The Spanish governor chooses the expression "en prolija" to match the Latin adjectives "longo et lugubri" ("long and anguished" (Yale 211 l.8). This means "long, dilated and excessively extended" according to the Diccionario de Autoridades.

The beginning part of this sentence in Medinilla's translation opposes what is actually stated in the Latin clauses "Quippe uictus ilia securitas, quae cuique domi est, ademptaque de posteris anxia cogitandi cura". The translator writes "Finalmente privados de aquella quietud y seguridad que cada uno tenía en su casa y de aquel ansioso cuidado de sus descendientes" (in English, "Finally deprived of that quiet and security that each one had in their home and that anxious care of their descendants", whereas the original says "The absence of anxiety about livelihood at home, as well as the removal of that worry which troubles men about the future of their families" (Yale 211 ll. 18-20).
The Spanish translator renders "ducem" as "príncipe" and "caudillo". See note ** for more information about the last term.

Medinilla translates "mediastinorum" as "gastadores". According to the Tesoro de la lengua, it refers to "in the army, the people who work with the shovel and the hoe and bring stone and clay and the rest that is necessary to make ditches, trenches, fortifications, platforms and everything else, because they use those materials". Robinson alternatively prefers "slaves". The original Latin word implies service or drudgery (Lewis and Short), which does not specifically coincides in sense with Medinilla's choice.

The Spanish translator uses the word "arma" with the sense of "armadura" (in English, "armour"). According to the Tesoro de la Lengua, the word "arma", which also means "weapon", in plural also means "harness or corselet" (fol. 88r). Interestingly, Medinilla adds that "es de los primeros ejercicios del arte militar" (in English, "one of the first military exercises learnt in military training"), which could imply it was the case of Spanish army. The original reads "nam armati natare inter militaris disciplinae rudimenta consuescunt" ("for they practice swimming under arms as part of their apprenticeship in military discipline" (Yale 213 ll. 36-38)).

The Spanish translator renders "praedia" (in English, "estates" (Yale, 215 l. 28)) as "heredades" (in English, "inheritances"). This is defined in the Tesoro de la Lengua as "the possession in the countryside of land, vineyards and trees" (fol. 466v).

Medinilla freely translates the part "in quos e suis ciuibus aliquos emittunt quaestorum nomine, qui magnifice uiuant, personamque magnatum illic prae se ferant" (in English, "To these states they dispatch some of their own citizens under the title of Financial Agents to live there in great style and to play the part of magnates" (Yale 215 ll.31-33)). However, the Spanish governor presents "a cuya cobranza envían algunos de sus ciudadanos con nombre de tesoreros, representando con obstentación la grandeza de su persona en aquellas partes" (in English, "to whose collection they send some of their citizens under the name of treasurers, obstinately representing the greatness of their person in those parts"). Also, while Robinson chooses "Lieutenauntes" for "quaestorum", Medinilla opts for "tesoreros" (in English, "treasurer"). Medinilla's term fits more appropriately to the meaning of that Latin term, since Robinson's choice does not have that financial sense --the OED defines it as "usually an officer civil or military who acts for a superior".
